Committee on Safety Albee to Teach 3 Courses
Referred to Larkin
by Timothy McNamara

Associate Dean of Administrative Services C. Nor.man Krueger has apparently
decided not to form a Committee on safety, as the Student Council requeste.d last
week.
Student Council President
Maureen Freed announced at
Wednesday night's Council
meeting that Krueger will not
form such a committee, but
will refer the matter to Major
Robert Larkin, manager of
the Campus Security Office.
Neither Krueger nor Larkin
could be reached for comment
yesterday.
"Unfortunately,
he
(Krueger) has decided he is
not going to chair the committee himself," Freed said, "and
instead he has chosen to refer
the matter to Larkin."
The Council also passed a
resolution which reiterates its
desire for Krueger to form
and chair a committee on
safety. The resolution, which

was proposed by Senior Class
President Mike Kun, states
that the Student Council
"once again urges" Krueger
to form a safety committee.
The Council, in a unanimously-passed resolution last
week, urged Krueger to form
a joint administrator/student
committee to evaluate campus
safety. The issue arose following a recent assault and an
Aug. 10 rape on the
Homewood campus.
Earlier in the week, Krueger
had said he planned to discuss
• the issue with the other deans
"to see what the appropriate
response would be." He added, however, that he thought
such a committee "sounds
reasonable."
Kruger also said at that time
that no one from the Student
Council had contacted him
about the issue, and that he
received a copy of the resolution only through campus
mail.

Committee
To Visit

Stoessel To Speak at MSE Symposium

A team of administrators
from other Universities will
visit Hopkins next week to
decide whether or not the
University will keep its
accreditation.
The team, which will be
chaired by University of Pennsylvania President Sheldon
Hackney, will receive presentations from various Hopkins administrators. Some undergraduates may also meet with
the team.
According to Associate Dean
of Undergraduate and Graduate Studies Lucien Brush, a
team of students "will be
available to meet with the Committee". He added, however,
that it will be the Committee's
decision whether or not to meet
with the students.
Asked if he believed the
Committee would want to meet
with the students, Brush said,
"I can't imagine that they
won't".
"Our concern when the
whole accreditation process
came up was what role
undergraduates would be playing in it," Education Committee Chairman Jon Lana said at
Wednesday night's Council
meeting. "At this point, Dean
Brush has given us his personal
guarantee that the University
would make every effort possible to involve undergraduates in
a formal manner," he added.

diplomat and ambassador, will
speak this fall in the 17th annual Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium.
Stoessel joins other MSE
speakers Zbigniew Brzezinski,
former national security advisor to President Carter, Sol
Linowitz, former envoy to the
Middle East Negotiation, and
Gabo Plaza, former Equadoran
president.

p.m., November 21 about the

"He is uniquely qualified,"
explained Paul Rubery, cochairman of the symposium,
"because he served as the
American ambassador to
Poland from 1968 to 1972 and
to the Soviet Union in Moscow
from 1974 to 1976. Also, he
was the Undersecretary of State
for Political Affairs from 1981
to 1983."
The symposium, an annual
tribute to the former Hopkins
president Milton S. Eisenhower, deals with various subjects like media, immigrant ex-

perience, and creativity.
This year's topic is "The
Dynamics of Foreign Policy: Is
the U.S. Compromising a Delicate Balance?" and will be entirely run by the Student Council, with additional funding
provided by outside companies.
Rubery said, "All major
universities have dignified
academic series, but they are
run by the administration. In
keeping with the Hopkins'
tradition, it is the students who
are running the symposium,
and I think this is very unique."
The symposium will begin
with Linowitz's lecture on

American foreign policy in the
Middle East on November 3.
Plaza will speak on November 16 about American foreign
policy in Latin America, and
Brzezinski will discuss American policy in general on
December 7.
All lectures will be held at
Shriver Hall. Admission is free
and open to the public.
"I hope that many people
will attend, because it is truly an
enjoyable, as well as educational, experience," concluded

Dorm Vandalism
To the editor:
We were told at the first
house meeting that restitution
for any damages incurred in the
dorms would be absorbed by
everyone in the dorm unless the
guilty party confessed.
At the time, I recall looking
around the room assessing the
destructive potential and integrity of my dorm mates. I was
satisfied that I was in good
company and would not have
to worry excessively about
happy-go-lucky vandalism. The

present problem never even occurred to me.
The problem that has arisen
is that since each house must
pay for damages to its property, people are going into other
dorms to spray off the fire extinguishers, puncture the ceiling
tiles, set off the fire alarm, or
pull down the exit signs,
;thereby
escaping
the
consequences.
I'm not condemning these
actions. I have nothing against
people enjoying themselves. If
this is how they derive their enjoyment, fine, but not when it
infringes on someone else.
These acts are not malicious.
For the most part, the
perpetrators just consider it
'fun'. Sometimes accidents
cause the destruction. For instance, someone might be playing lacrosse in the hall and the
ball knocks into the exit sign
and cracks it. Granted, accidents occur, but the fact remains someone must pay.
Another grating fact is that
on most occasions, there have
been witnesses. But no one
wants to say who's responsible.
And no one should have to.
Instead, I'm suggesting that
people begin to take responsibility for their actions. Mom
and Dad aren't here to watch
out for us and smooth the way
when we make mistakes. We
should own up to the 'fun' we
commit or don't do it at all.
Sincerely,
Jung Chun

There seems to have to be a
new interest in the "standard"
American popular song these
days. Rolling Stone, of all
magazines, printed a full page
obituary of lyricist Howard
Dietz, an Irving Berlin song was
recently in the Top Ten, and
Elvis Costello not only lists
Billie Holliday and Frank
Sinatra as his major singing influences, but admits that he
aspires to be the Cole Porter of
the Eighties. In the last two years
Willie Nelson and Carly Simon
have recorded albums of old
standards, Nelson with some
cuccess and Simon with absolutely none. On her last EP,
Rickie Lee Jones made dismal
attempts at "Stardust" and
"Lush Life," and now Linda
Ronstadt has entered the contest with What's New?
Ronstadt's album is more
successful than the others,
primarly because she had the
good sense to hire Nelson Riddle, whose name became
synonomous with the art of arranging through his work with
Frank Sinatra in the fifties.
Riddle's job here is to add emotion to the songs, since
Ronstadt, though her voice is
quite pretty, doesn't have the
emotional depth these songs require. Riddle's arrangements
are never obtrusive, and complement Ronstadt's singing nicely. She is not a first-rate singer,
but second-rate versions of
first-rate songs are still easy on
the ears, and What's New is a
pleasing, if not memorable,
album.
Mel Torme emerged from the
jungles of Vegas a few years
ago and began recording jazz
songs again. When he disappeared to Vegas he was already
considered a fine singer; when
he returned he was even better.
Torme has just released his second collaboration with pianist
George Shearing, Top Drawer,
and it is every bit as wonderful
as their Grammy-winning live
album. Without the use of an
orchestra, Shearing, Torme and
bassist Don Thompson manage
to slip into some marvelous
Shvinging grooves without any
effort at all. They add new life
to the old standards (dig the
bop choruses on "Smoke Gets
in Your Eyes" and the melody
changes in "Stardust") without
altering the essential beauty of
the songs. On the ballad, Mel's
voice hangs lightly in the air,
while on the faster tunes he and
Shearing spin long lines around
and around each other, then
slip into flawless unison.
Thompson adds to the brew
with his deft basslines, and the
result is the best vocal album of
the year.(Of course, An Evening with George Shearing and
Mel Torme was the best vocal
of '82, and Mel Torme Live at
Marty's was same for '81.) Mel
is the best singer around, and

Top Drawer should not be
missed. Pick up the other two
while you're at it.
Any discussion of singers
must mention the tragic death
last month of Johnny Hartman. Twenty years ago Ella Fitzgerald called Hartman the
most under-rated and underrecorded singer in the world,
and that didn't change in his
last years. Hartman had a deep,
rich baritone that was always
emotionally charged; when he
sang a ballad you felt as though
he was sitting in the room with
you, talking things out. Hartman will always be remembered
for his 1963 collaboration with
John Coltrane, perhaps the

Mel Forme: better than ever

classic jazz vocal album, which
includes the definitive reading
of Billy Strayhorn's "Lush

Life." Johnny was little
known, and so probably won't
be missed by too many people,

but those of us who heard him
will miss him sorely.

The Johns Hopkins Men's
Swim team has won three Division III National Titles and
placed in the top five at Division II Nationals in the last five
years, including a fourth place

The Jays have had 42 allAmericans in a total of 190
events in the last 10 years. They
have also won 13 straight MAC
championship titles, going for

Blue Jays begin training this
month, their goal is to continue
this tradition of good swimming and hopefully to improve
as they have never done before.
Tim Welsh is entering his
seventh year as head coach of
the Blue Jays, and is optimistic about the team's prospects. "For the first time in a
while, we will be able to cover
all the events in dual meets this
year." He said,"We have some
good freshmen and the returning swimmers seem ready for a
good season."
The team is led by three
senior captains: Bob Britanisky, a solid national performer
in breastroke and individual
medly; Bob Dyer, a breastroker
and a strong motivator; and
Mike Leonhardt, one of the
best swimmers in Hopkins
history.
Serious training for the team
began early this month and will
continue until the middle of
March, the date of the Division
III Nationals. This season is
one of the longest official
seasons in collegiate sports. It
is also one of the toughest
mentally.
According to Welsh, "In
swimming, especially at our

ference in natural ability between swimmers, for the majority of athletes, is small."
"Therefore in a race between
swimmers of equal natural
talent, two factors will determine who wins the race. The
first is, the amount of training
and background work done
before the race. The second,
and more difficult to realize, is
the amount of mental preparation done before the race."
Mental training includes confidence, race strategy, visualization and relaxation. "Hopkins
swimmers," continued Welsh,
"usually are too-keyed up
before a race. We need to let go
and not force it, especially right
before a race because by that
time, any added stress is
detrimental."
With this in mind, the team
will spend more time on "group
mental training" than in the
past.
With regards to basic training, most of the swimmers lift
weights three times a week and

;thereby

the

perpetrators just consider it
'fun'. Sometimes accidents

and cracks it. Granted, accidents occur, but the fact remains someone must pay.

on most occasions, there have
been witnesses. But no one
wants to say who's responsible.
And no one should have to.
Instead, I'm suggesting that
people begin to take responsibility for their actions. Mom
and Dad aren't here to watch
out for us and smooth the way
when we make mistakes. We
should own up to the 'fun' we
commit or don't do it at all.

The Johns Hopkins Men's
Swim team has won three Division III National Titles and
placed in the top five at Division II Nationals in the last five
years, including a fourth place
finish last year.
The Jays have had 42 allAmericans in a total of 190
events in the last 10 years. They
have also won 13 straight MAC
championship titles, going for
number 14 this season. As the
Blue Jays begin training this
month, their goal is to continue
this tradition of good swimming and hopefully to improve
as they have never done before.
Tim Welsh is entering his
seventh year as head coach of
the Blue Jays, and is optimistic about the team's prospects. "For the first time in a
while, we will be able to cover
all the events in dual meets this
year." He said,"We have some
good freshmen and the returning swimmers seem ready for a
good season."
The team is led by three
senior captains: Bob Britanisky, a solid national performer
in breastroke and individual
medly; Bob Dyer, a breastroker
and a strong motivator; and
Mike Leonhardt, one of the
best swimmers in Hopkins
history.
Serious training for the team
began early this month and will
continue until the middle of
March, the date of the Division
III Nationals. This season is
one of the longest official
seasons in collegiate sports. It
is also one of the toughest
mentally.
According to Welsh, "In
swimming, especially at our

ference in natural ability between swimmers, for the majority of athletes, is small."
"Therefore in a race between
swimmers of equal natural
talent, two factors will determine who wins the race. The
first is, the amount of training
and background work done
before the race. The second,
and more difficult to realize, is
the amount of mental preparation done before the race."
Mental training includes confidence, race strategy, visualization and relaxation. "Hopkins
swimmers," continued Welsh,
"usually are too-keyed up
before a race. We need to let go
and not force it, especially right
before a race because by that
time, any added stress is
detrimental."
With this in mind, the team
will spend more time on "group
mental training" than in the
past.
With regards to basic training, most of the swimmers lift
weights three times a week and
attend eight of nine practices a
week. The yardage varies from
5,000(three miles) to 7,000(4.5
miles) a practice.
"We stress training for individual events," explained
Welsh, "but we also stress endurance and that combination
gives us an advantage over
other Division III teams.
When asked why Hopkins
has dominated the MAC's for
over a decade, Welsh responded enthusiastically, "First
of all, Hopkins, with its excellent academic reputation and
swimming tradition, draws
many excellent swimmers
already capable of Division III
National times. Second, we

the other teams, and third of
all, we're big on improvement." Improvement is a big
factor. Every swimmer in coach
Welsh's program has improved
in at least one event and usually in more.
Besides winning their fourteenth MAC championship this
season, the Jays are concentrating on placing higher at Nationals. "For this to happen,"
said Welsh, "we are going to
have to work harder as individuals but more importantly as a team. We have a lot of
potential, but in order to
minimize our performance, we
have to work together."

national qualifiers (including
two divers) this year. Leading
the list are multiple AllAmerican, defending (1650) national champion Mike Leonhardt; Junior All-Americans
Dick Johnson, Steve Segreto,
and Tom Uristek; and sophomore All-Americans Wink
Dyer and Kevin Anderson. But
the people who will be crucial
to Hopkins success are the
other performers on the team,
whose improvement is essential.

is the annual Comfort Classic
Intersquad Scrimmage on
November 5. The team is looking forward to the meet for two
reasons, but especially to see
where they stand after a month
of hard training. For those
students who have never been
